metadata.case_name: Martinez v. Acme Trucking, Inc. and James Wilson

witness.name: Carlos Rodriguez
witness.credibility_assessment: Highly credible independent eyewitness with no connection to either party. Rodriguez was positioned with a clear, unobstructed view of the intersection from approximately 30-40 feet away. His testimony is consistent, detailed, and corroborated by the physical evidence. He has no stake in the outcome and volunteered to provide a statement to police at the scene.
witness.demeanor_notes: Confident and consistent throughout testimony. Did not waver under cross-examination. Provided specific details without embellishment.
key_strengths: Independent witness with no relationship to parties
Clear, unobstructed view of the accident
Consistent testimony that matches physical evidence
30 years driving experience for speed estimation
No promise of compensation for testimony

executive_summary:
Carlos Rodriguez provides powerful corroborating testimony for the plaintiff's case. As an independent eyewitness with no connection to either party, his observations carry significant weight.

Key findings: Rodriguez confirms that Ms. Martinez had the walk signal and was legally in the crosswalk. He observed the truck run the red light without stopping. Most critically, he saw the driver's head down—appearing to look at something in his lap—immediately before impact. He heard the driver admit at the scene: 'I didn't see her' and 'I was already running late. My dispatcher is going to kill me.'

Rodriguez's testimony directly contradicts any defense theory that Martinez was at fault or that the driver was paying attention to the road. His observations about the driver's fatigue ('His eyes were red, like he hadn't slept much') corroborate the fatigue evidence from Wilson's own deposition.
narrative_summary:
Carlos Rodriguez was waiting at the bus stop on the corner of Atlantic and Flatbush on the morning of October 14, 2025, at approximately 7:30 AM. He was on his way to work and was watching the intersection because he was considering crossing there himself.

Rodriguez observed Maria Martinez begin crossing Atlantic Avenue in the crosswalk. He specifically noted that the pedestrian walk signal was solid white (not flashing), indicating she had just received the signal to cross and was legally in the crosswalk.

As Martinez crossed, Rodriguez saw a commercial truck traveling east on Atlantic Avenue approach the intersection. According to Rodriguez, the truck was traveling at approximately 35-40 mph—significantly over the 25 mph speed limit. The traffic light for Atlantic Avenue was red.

Most significantly, Rodriguez observed that the driver's head was down immediately before the impact. 'He was looking down, like he was looking at something in his lap. Maybe a phone.' Rodriguez noted that the driver's head was down for 'at least a few seconds' before the collision.

The truck struck Martinez without any apparent attempt to stop. Rodriguez did not hear any horn or brake sounds before impact. After the collision, the truck continued for 20-30 feet before stopping.

Rodriguez approached the scene and spoke briefly with the driver. He heard the driver say 'I didn't see her' and 'I was already running late. My dispatcher is going to kill me.' Rodriguez also observed that the driver 'looked tired' with 'red eyes, like he hadn't slept much.'

Rodriguez remained at the scene and provided a statement to the responding police officer.

key_statements.quote: She had the walk signal... The white walk sign was lit up.
It was red. The light had just turned red.
He was looking down. I could see through the windshield. His head was down, like he was looking at something in his lap. Maybe a phone.
Fast. Too fast. I'd say at least 35 or 40 miles per hour.
I heard him say something like, 'Oh God, I didn't see her.'
He said he was trying to make the light.
He said, 'I was already running late. My dispatcher is going to kill me.'
key_statements.significance: Explains why driver was rushing/not paying attention

key_statements.quote: He looked tired. His eyes were red, like he hadn't slept much.
No. No horn. I didn't hear any brakes screeching either. It was like the driver didn't even try to stop.

settlement_impact.reasoning:
Rodriguez's testimony as an independent eyewitness significantly strengthens the plaintiff's case beyond what was established in Wilson's own deposition. His observations corroborate every key element of plaintiff's theory: Martinez was crossing legally, Wilson was distracted (head down), Wilson was speeding, Wilson ran the red light, and Wilson made admissions at the scene.

The fact that Rodriguez has no connection to either party and no financial interest in the outcome makes his testimony particularly valuable. Juries tend to credit independent eyewitnesses, especially when their observations align with other evidence.

Rodriguez's observation that the driver's 'head was down' provides visual corroboration for the cell phone records showing texting two minutes before impact. His testimony about the driver looking tired with 'red eyes' corroborates the fatigue evidence.

This deposition eliminates any viable defense theory that Martinez was at fault or that Wilson was operating his vehicle safely. Combined with Wilson's own damaging admissions, the case for liability is now overwhelming.
